org.spicetrade.tools.Item.name: Weapons
org.spicetrade.tools.Item.description: You can have two have two kinds of weapons in the game: dagger and magic sword. The dagger is a basic weapon you use in battles. The magic sword can be found in an Assyrian god king grave. It is almost invincible.

org.spicetrade.tools.Item.name: Soldier
org.spicetrade.tools.Item.description: When you have established your markets in European cities you can also rent a home for yourself in these cities. A home abroad stabilizes your cultural influence in these countries.

org.spicetrade.tools.Item.name: purveyor
org.spicetrade.tools.Item.description: You can hire a purveyour in bazaar to take care of you art business. Purveyor can automatically give orders to artists to fill your museum and library with various works of arts.

org.spicetrade.tools.Item.name: food
org.spicetrade.tools.Item.description: You need your daily basic food to keep your health good enough to travel and take care of your business. You can also buy in bazaar rich food which gives you extra physical strength. You can also buy luxury food which is increasing your happiness and cultural capital.

org.spicetrade.tools.Item.name: home abroad
org.spicetrade.tools.Item.description: When you have established your markets in European cities you can also rent home for yourself in these cities. Home abroad stabilizes your cultural influence in these countries.

org.spicetrade.tools.Item.name: Fort of Anjoudan
org.spicetrade.tools.Item.description: Hasan-i-Sabah is also known as the Old Man of the Mountain. He built the famous Alamut fortress from which he controlled the Central Asian politics by means of assassinations and intrigue. It is rumoured that he is immortal and that in his Alamut fortress, his soldiers have the pleasures of the paradise in their use. In this game, he has started to build new fortresses. One of these is being built near the city of Anjudan.

org.spicetrade.tools.Item.name: Shrine of Ali
org.spicetrade.tools.Item.description: In the middle of the city of Najaf there is the Shrine of the Imam Ali Ibn Abi Talib, cousin of the Prophet, with its resplendent golden dome and minarets. Great quantities of priceless objects, gifts of potentates and sultans, are kept in the treasury of the mosque. Historians say the tomb of Ali at Najaf was very likely built by Azoud ad Dowleh in 366 AH; that it was burnt later and rebuilt by the Seljuk Malik Shah in 479 AH; and rebuilt yet again by Ismail Shah, the Safawid, in about 900 AH. No doubt numerous other hands have tinkered with it since. The tomb has the same style as those of Kerbela, Samarra and Kadhimain. The Shrine of Ali is the holiest shrine in Shia Islam, and it is sacred to Sunni Muslims, too.

org.spicetrade.tools.Item.name: Al-Qadirya Shrine
org.spicetrade.tools.Item.description: Named in honour of the saint, the Abd al-Qadir al Jilani shrine complex is one of the most important sanctuaries in Baghdad. It lies in the eastern part of the city in al-Rusafah neighbourhood. The complex houses the tomb of this saint as well as a mosque and a madrasa, all within one enclosure. The mosque was first built during the saint's life. Abd al-Qadir al Jilani was born in 469 AH. There he taught his doctrine of Islam that became known as al-Qadiriya.§§The complex is accessible by two entrances located on the east and west facades. They both open onto the courtyard that is surrounded by cells distributed on one floor to form the complex enclosure. In the courtyard, in front of the main building housing the mosque and the shrine, is a fenced platform with an outdoor mihrab for summer prayers.§§The tomb, situated to the eastern side of the prayer hall, is accessible from the eastern and the northern ambulatory where three domes delimit the entrance. The tomb has a square plan topped by a dome on muquarnas squinches. The lower part of its four walls is tiled with marble while the upper part is covered with mirror decoration. On the lower part of the dome runs a band of inscription. Below the dome in the middle of the room lies the wooden sarcophagus of the saint.

org.spicetrade.tools.Item.name: Mausoleum of Imam Mustansir
org.spicetrade.tools.Item.description: The mausoleum of Imam Mustansir is the oldest surviving Nizari Ismaili monument in Anjudan; which is an imposing octagonal building with a dome, appearing conical from outside. Ismailis in Persia passed through a long period of unexpected calamity and continuous persecution in the form of the Mongol invasion and mass killings by Tamarlane. Therefore, for many years, Isrnailis had to live under strictest secrecy in Persia. Anjudan and later Kahak came to be known as the residences of the Imams. However, Ismailism continued to grow in the sub-continent of India during Imamat of Mevlana Mustansir-bi-Lah II, Mevlana Abdas-Salaam and Mevlana Ghareeb Mirza.§§Imam Mustansir stayed in Anjudan as his summer villa, where a small numbers of followers inhabited. He died in Kahek in 880 AH, but was buried in Anjudan, most probably in pursuant of his will. Later on, a mausoleum was erected in Anjudan. In the middle of the chamber, there is a wooden coffin, exquisitely carved. At the bottom is written: "Wrote this the humble slave Abdul Jalil in 885 AH". This leads us that the wooden box was erected by the order of Abdus Salam, the son and successor of Mustansir, most probably five years after latter's death.

org.spicetrade.tools.Item.name: Naissa Mosque
org.spicetrade.tools.Item.description: The Naissa mosque consists of an octagonal prayer hall covered by a dome that is pierced by twenty-four coloured glass windows. Outside, a courtyard, with a marble-mosaic water fountain in the middle, is connected to the mosque by porticoes. Also included in the scheme is a library situated behind the southern portico, and a reception hall behind the eastern portico. The form of the mosque is related to the Dome of the Rock in Jerusalem in its octagonal shape and dome form. The transparency of the porticoes on the main elevation achieve a central lightness that is inviting, while at the same time being weighted down at either end by the minaret and the dome of the prayer hall. The minaret and reception hall also balance the opposing volumes of the courtyard and the prayer hall.

org.spicetrade.tools.Item.name: Dzhuma Mosque
org.spicetrade.tools.Item.description: The Dzhuma Mosque is one of the oldest Muslim places of worship in the former Soviet Union dating back to the 80’s AH In spite of all the seismic activity, some ancient buildings have survived, and are worth seeing. The Dzhuma Mosque has been rebuilt several times, but it dates back to the 4th century AH, making it one of the oldest buildings still standing in the town and the oldest mosque in the Caucasus, occupying the site of an ancient sun worshipers’ temple.

org.spicetrade.tools.Item.name: Tomb of Mevlana
org.spicetrade.tools.Item.description: The city Konya, which was the capital of the Anatolian Seljuks for more than 200 years, is unique concerning the richness of the architectural works belonging to this period. Mevlana Dzalaladdin Rumi died here in Konya in 671 AH. In the Tomb of Mevlana there are various Korans, vases, musical instruments and carpets belonging to the Seljuks, and various items belonging to the Mevlevis, and under the tomb, which is covered on the exterior with green glazed tiles, are the sarcophagi of Mevlana and his father. The tomb of Sems-i Tebrizi, the teacher and close friend of Mevlana, is covered with an octagonal pyramid and it is located near the Mevlana Museum.

org.spicetrade.tools.Item.name: Shrine of Hafaza
org.spicetrade.tools.Item.description: When you are introduced to Hafaza by Mahdi you have to build a shrine in her honour. One way to contact Hafaza is to pray at the Shrine of Hafaza and get her blessing. Another way is to pray with a rosary which you can do anywhere.

org.spicetrade.tools.Item.name: Constantinople market place
org.spicetrade.tools.Item.description: At the Constantinople market place, you can sell your spices. When your business expands, you can rent yourself business a store in the market.

org.spicetrade.tools.Item.name: Palace of Constantinople
org.spicetrade.tools.Item.description: Constantinople is ruled by Michael VIII Palaelogus (659-681 AH), but because you are Muslim you have to get all your permits from the palace of the Ottoman sultan Osman Gazi (679-724 AH). It is wise to be on good terms with the palace personnel.

org.spicetrade.tools.Item.name: Constantinople restaurant
org.spicetrade.tools.Item.description: The restaurant is located at the port of Constantinople. The wine bar is a good place to find yourself a local friend.

org.spicetrade.tools.Item.name: Port of Constantinople
org.spicetrade.tools.Item.description: The port of Constantinople is located by the Golden Horn. Ships can sail from here to the Sea of Marmara. At the port you can go to the restaurant and get some new friends.

org.spicetrade.tools.Item.name: Blue Mosque
org.spicetrade.tools.Item.description: The Blue Mosque was founded by Sultan Ahmet I. He ordered Architect Mehmed Aga to begin construction in 1018 AH and the whole complex was completed in 1025 AH. The location of the mosque is just opposite of the splendid Church of Hagia Sophia as if it is trying to compete with it. That is actually true because Architect Mehmed wanted to construct a bigger dome than Hagia Sophia's but he did not succeed. Instead, he made the mosque splendid by the perfect proportion of domes and semidomes as well as the splendid minarets. There is an interesting story of the mosque; according to old story, Sultan Ahmet I wanted to have a minaret made of gold which is "altin" in Turkish. The architect misunderstood him as "alti" which means "six" in English. However, when the architect was shivering as "am I going to be beheaded?" the Sultan Ahmed I liked the minarets so much because no sultan had a mosque with six minarets.

org.spicetrade.tools.Item.name: Bank of Constantinople
org.spicetrade.tools.Item.description: In the bank, you can rent business premises. The bank also acts as a currency exchange. The currency exchange only operates in peace time: if you are at war with another country, the currency exchange will not work.

org.spicetrade.tools.Item.name: Grave of Tiglath-Pileser I
org.spicetrade.tools.Item.description: When you have collected all four sections of maps, you will see a red cross on the city map showing location of the grave of an Assyrian god king. In the grave of Tiglath-Pileser I, there are treasures, fetishes and the buckle of the guardian god Ningizzia, which will protect your property. Ningizzia is a guardian of the gate of heaven and a god of the underworld in Assyrian pantheon. Tiglath-Pileser I ruled the Assyrian Empire from 1791-1752 BH.

org.spicetrade.tools.Item.name: Grave of Ashurbanipal
org.spicetrade.tools.Item.description: When you have collected all four sections of maps, you will see a red cross on the city map showing the location of the grave of an Assyrian god king. In the grave of Ashurbanipal, there are treasures, fetishes and the buckle of the ear god Geshtu-e, which will protect you from slandering. Geshtu-e is a god whose blood and intelligence are used by Mami to create man in Assyrian mythology. As the last powerful king of Assyria, he developed the first collection of written texts that included not only records and temple archives, but also a variety of works on diverse topics. Ashurbanipal was king from 1331 to 1288 BH. He was not only a great warrior, which was expected of an Assyrian king, he was also a hunter and a high priest of the god Assur.

org.spicetrade.tools.Item.name: Grave of Eriba-Adad
org.spicetrade.tools.Item.description: When you have collected all four sections of maps, you will see a red cross on the city map showing the location of the grave of an Assyrian god king. In the grave of Eriba-Adad, there are treasures, fetishes and the buckle of the growth god Tammuz, which will increase the growth of crops. Tammuz is the brother and spouse to Ishtar, the lover of her youth. He is a vegetation god. He went into the underworld and was recovered through the intervention of Ishtar. He is sometimes the guardian of heaven's gates and sometimes a god of the underworld. He is friends with Ningizzia. He is exchanged for Ishtar in the Underworld. Eriba-Adad’s, son of Tiglath-Pileser I, reign (1729-1728 BH) was undistinguished and his short reign may have been due to his inability to prevent the disintegration of the once mighty Assyrian empire.

org.spicetrade.tools.Item.name: Grave of Puzur-Ashur III
org.spicetrade.tools.Item.description: When you have collected all four sections of maps, you will see a red cross on the city map showing the location of the grave of an Assyrian god king. In the grave of Puzur-Ashur III, there are treasures, fetishes and the buckle of the god Urshamb, which will give you success on sea voyages. Urshamb is boatman to Utmapishtim in Assyrian mythology. Puzur-Ashur III reigned Assyria 2185 - 2170 BH.

org.spicetrade.tools.Item.name: Grave of Sargon II
org.spicetrade.tools.Item.description: When you have collected all four sections of maps, you will see a red cross on the city map showing the location of the grave of an Assyrian god king. In the grave of Shalim-Ahu, there are treasures, fetishes and the buckle of the god Apsu, which will help you to sort out your personal relationships. Apsu is a primeval Sumero-Akkadian god who personifies the primordial abyss of sweet waters underneath the earth. He is the consort of Tiamat, the primordial abyss of salt waters of Chaos. In the later mythology of the Enuma Elish, the sweet water mingled with the bitter waters of the sea and with a third watery element, perhaps a cloud. The first gods were engendered. Shalim-Ahu was the king of early Assyrian period. They were called "kings who lived in tents".

org.spicetrade.tools.Item.name: Grave of Shalim-Ahu
org.spicetrade.tools.Item.description: When you have collected all four sections of maps, you will see red cross on the city map showing location of the grave of Assyrian god king. In the grave of Shalim-Ahu, there are treasures, fetishes and the buckle of the god Apsu, which will help you to sort out your personal relationships. Apsu is a primeval Sumero-Akkadian god who personifies the primordial abyss of sweet waters underneath the earth. He is the consort of Tiamat, the primordial abyss of salt waters of Chaos. In the later mythology of the Enuma Elish, the sweet water mingled with the bitter waters of the sea and with a third watery element, perhaps cloud, the first gods were engendered. Shalim-Ahu was the king of early Assyrian period. They were called "kings who lived in tents".

org.spicetrade.tools.Item.name: Grave of Ilu-Shuma
org.spicetrade.tools.Item.description: When you have collected all four sections of maps, you will see red cross on the city map showing location of the grave of Assyrian god king. In the grave of Ilu-Shuma, there are treasures, fetishes and the buckle of the god Tiamat, which will help you to win the game. In Babylonian myths, Tiamat is a huge, bloated female dragon that personifies the saltwater ocean, the water of Chaos. She is also the primordial mother of all that exists, including the gods themselves. Her consort is Apsu, the personification of the freshwater abyss that lies beneath the Earth. From their union, saltwater with freshwater, the first pair of gods were born. Ilu-Shuma was the king of early Assyrian period. They were called "kings who lived in tents".

org.spicetrade.tools.Item.name: Amsterdam
org.spicetrade.tools.Item.description: Amsterdam originated as a small fishing village in the 7th century AH. To protect themselves from floods, the early inhabitants had to build dikes on both sides of the river, and about 668 AH they built a dam between these dikes. Even then, merchant ships from Amsterdam sailed as far as the Baltic Sea and laid the foundation of the future trade centre, acting as a link between northern Europe and Flanders. After the Netherlands passed to the Spanish crown in the 10th century AH, a religious and political rebellion against Spanish oppression spread across the region. Amsterdam hesitated to join the rebellion led by William I the Silent, prince of Orange, but in 986 AH there was a bloodless revolution in the city.§§Amsterdam was still a small city with no more than about 30 000 inhabitants, but things changed quickly, especially in 993 AH, when Spanish troops recaptured Antwerp, then the dominant port and commercial centre of the Netherlands. Dutch forces responded by blockading the Schelde River, Antwerp's only access to the sea. The fall of Antwerp led to a wholesale influx of mainly Protestant refugees into the towns of the northern Netherlands, especially Amsterdam. Their arrival enriched the city's intellectual, cultural, and commercial life.§§Banking and shipbuilding especially flourished. Much of the trade formerly concentrated in Antwerp then moved to Amsterdam. Along with the Flemish merchants came hundreds of Jews who had been expelled from Portugal. Other Jews followed from the area of modern Germany and Eastern Europe. The city soon became a trading metropolis, whose population more than tripled between 972 AH and 1027 AH. Merchant ships from Amsterdam not only sailed to the Baltic and the Mediterranean but also plied the long sea route to the East Indies and established colonies in South America and southern Africa.

org.spicetrade.tools.Item.name: Madrid
org.spicetrade.tools.Item.description: The Arab town, or medina, grew around the alcazar on a promontory overlooking the Manzanares River. The name Majerit first appears in 320 AH, when the Christian king Ramiro II of León razed the town's walls, but there are traces of earlier habitation. The Christian king Alfonso VI of Castile and León captured the town from the Muslims in 475 AH, and thereafter a number of kings of Castile spent time there. The parliament was called there as early as 705 AH. The alcazar was damaged in an earthquake in 1466 and the subsequent medieval palace was extended by various monarchs, notably Charles I and Philip II. In this period the town grew to the east up both sides of what are now the Calle Mayor and the Calle de Segovia. The Moors, who continued to live there until after the Christian reconquest of Spain was completed in 870 AH, jammed into the southwest corner, which is still called the Moreria.§§The whole of the city at this time was only 460 by 820 meters in area. Some of the street patterns of the pre-16th century city remain, but only a few buildings. One that still stands is the much-restored Casa de los Lujanes, where it is believed the French king Francis I was once held prisoner. Charles I enjoyed hunting near Madrid, and it is said that the widening of the city gates to accommodate his carriages opened the cramped streets to heavier traffic, a process that was to increase when the court was properly established in the city. By 1006 AH the population of Madrid had reached 60 000, and by the time of the first extant plan of Madrid it had grown to be an imposing city of 100 000 people and 11 000 buildings.

org.spicetrade.tools.Item.name: Moscow
org.spicetrade.tools.Item.description: The first documentary reference to Moscow is found in the early monastic chronicles under the year 541 AH, when on April 4 Yury Vladimirovich Dolgoruky, prince of Suzdal, was host ata "great banquet" for his ally the Prince of Novgorod-Seversky "in Moscow." This is the traditional date of Moscow's foundation, although archaeological evidence shows that a settlement had existed on the site since Neolithic times.§§Moscow soon developed as one of the more important towns of the principality of Vladimir-Suzdal. A trading settlement, or posad, grew up to the east of the Kremlin, along the Moskva in the area known as Zaradye. Like most other Russian towns, Moscow was captured and burned by the Mongols in their great invasion of 633–637 AH, and its princes had to accept Mongol sovereignty. It soon recovered, though the Mongols sacked it once again in 692 AH. Three years later, the Kremlin was strengthened with a new earthen wall and oak palisade. Thereafter Moscow grew in importance, in trading, artisan activities, and in size, overtaking the older and previously more important centres of Suzdal and Vladimir.§§The town was fairly centrally placed in the system of rivers and portages that formed the trade routes across European Russia. The area east of Moscow between the Oka and Volga rivers moreover had better soil than most of northern Russia and formed a region of well developed agriculture and prosperous towns. Moscow's authority was greatly enhanced when in 726 AH the Metropolitan of the Russian Orthodox Church transferred his seat from Vladimir to Moscow. Thereafter the town was to remain the centre of Russian Orthodoxy, and after the fall of Constantinople to the Turks in 857 AH it claimed the title of the Third Rome. Under Ivan I Kalita the principality of Vladimir was incorporated into that of Moscow. Gradually the princes of Moscow extended their rule over the other surrounding Russian princedoms, and the town became the leader in the long struggle against Mongol hegemony.

org.spicetrade.tools.Item.name: Hamburg
org.spicetrade.tools.Item.description: Hamburg's history begins with the Hammaburg, a moated castle of modest size, built in about 209 AH on a sandy promontory between the Alster and Elbe rivers. In 219 AH, during the reign of the emperor Louis the Pious, the castle's baptistery became the seat of an archbishopric. Archbishop Ansgar made the young city of Hamburg the base of his missions to the heathens of northern Europe. Vikings burned the city in 230 AH, and the rebuilt Hamburg was burned down again eight times in the following 300 years.§§By the end of the 5th century, Hamburg's role as the spiritual metropolis of the north was over, and they concentrated in commerce. Between 513 AH and 534 AH some trading businesses were installed, and the foundation of Lübeck, on the Baltic, by Adolf II, further promoted the economic development of Hamburg as Lübeck's port on the North Sea. In 584 AH a group of Hamburg entrepreneurs received from their feudal overlord, Adolph III adjacent to the old one, with a harbour on the Alster River and with facilities for the use of the Elbe River as an outer roadstead.§§In the 7th century AH Hamburg grew steadily in both area and economic importance, due to the development of the Hanse into a widespread association of north German merchant cities, the great Hanseatic League, in which Hamburg's role was second only to Lübeck's. A major entrepôt for the trade between Russia and Flanders, Hamburg proceeded to safeguard the trade routes by acquiring tracts of land along the branches of the Elbe in the immediate vicinity of the town and also on the estuary farther downstream.

org.spicetrade.tools.Item.name: Budapest
org.spicetrade.tools.Item.description: Budapest's location is a prime site for habitation because of its geography. There is ample evidence of human settlement on the Danube's western side from Neolithic times onward. Kurszán, the Magyar tribal chieftain, probably took up residence in the palace of the former Roman governor at the end of the 3rd century.§§Medieval Buda prospered and declined along with its patron, the Hungarian royal court. The municipality was established by royal charter in 641 AH, by Béla IV. He bestowed on the citizens of Pest, whose town had been devastated by the Mongols in 638 AH. The town administration, based on German law, had been dominated by German burghers before it became reorganized in 843 AH. The palace was rebuilt by Matthias I, whose death in 895 AH marked the decline of both royal power and the town. The Turks held Buda between 948 AH and 1097 AH. After a devastating siege it was liberated by a Christian army organized by the Holy Roman emperor Leopold I. Little of Matthias' Buda survived into the 12th century AH.

org.spicetrade.tools.Item.name: Vienna
org.spicetrade.tools.Item.description: Emperor Marcus Aurelius is said to have died in Vindobona in 456 BH fighting off attacks by the Germanic tribes. The Romans were swept away in the turmoil of the 1st century BH invasions. The Bavarians occupied the area, and the people became Christianized. The city's name was recorded in 267 AH as Wenia and in 421 AH as Wienis.§§In 644 AH the last male of the Babenberg family died. In the ensuing struggle for domination, the king of Bohemia, Otakar II, became overlord of what was to become Austria. Otakar established himself as a powerful central European prince, and by 674 AH he was at war with the German king, Rudolf I of the Habsburg dynasty. When Otakar fell in battle in 677 AH, the Habsburgs took over his domain and retained it for more than 600 years. The capital city flourished, trading with Trieste, Venice, and Hungary; nevertheless, economic decline attended the numerous disputes over inheritance within the Habsburg family. In 890 AH, under siege by Matthias I Corvinus of Hungary, the city fathers surrendered in the hope of bettering their status. When Corvinus died five years later, Vienna reverted to the Habsburg emperor. When Charles V became Holy Roman emperor in the 10th century, he entrusted his Austrian territories to his brother, the future emperor Ferdinand I. Seeking to increase their liberties and economic position, the Lower Austrian Dietrebelled against their regent. Ferdinand responded by condemning the leaders of the insurrection to death, and in 932 AH he issued an ordinance that stripped the city of almost all its rights. In the same year, he inherited the kingdoms of Bohemia and Hungary and, accordingly, the task of fighting the Turks, who commanded large parts of Hungary. Turkish forces besieged Vienna in 935 AH but were successfully beaten off. When Ferdinand was crowned emperor in 965 AH, Vienna regained its political status and became the administrative seat of numerous kingdoms that the Habsburgs acquired by marriage.

org.spicetrade.tools.Item.name: Venice
org.spicetrade.tools.Item.description: Uniquely among Italy's chief cities, Venice came into being after the fall of the Roman Empire in the West. The Lombard hordes, whose incursions into northern Italy began in 55 BH, drove great numbers of mainlanders onto the islands of the lagoon, previously the homes of itinerant fishermen and salt workers. The first elected doge, or duke, was Orso. There followed decades of internal political strife among various settlements vying for supremacy and between pro- and anti-Byzantine factions. Finally the doge Obelerio and his brother Beato formed an alliance with the Franks of Italy and placed Venice under the authority of the Italian king Pippin in order to free themselves from Byzantine control.§§The unusual legal and political position of the small independent situated duchy, situated in territorial isolation between two great empires, contributed greatly to its function as a trading intermediary. Beginning in the late 9th century, the doges were chosen by popular election, though the right was frequently abused during times of civil strife. Finally the group of Rialto islands was solemnly transformed into the city of Venice. The final collapse of family faction rule led to a change in the system of government, inaugurated by Doge Domenico Flabanico (422–433 AH). A new church was built for St Mark, symbol of the Venetian spirit, under Doge Domenico Contarini (434–462 AH), an energetic defender of the religious independence of the duchy.§§In 662 AH the Byzantine emperor in exile at Nicaea, with the support of the Genoese, recovered the city and evicted the Venetians. The emperor rewarded the Genoese with privileges that challenged the Venetian monopoly of trade and opened up to Genoa the Black Sea markets. The Venetians retained control of many of the Greek islands, however, and gradually found their way back to partial favour in Byzantium through a series of treaties. But when the last of the crusader strongholds in Syria fell to the Muslims in 690 AH, Venetian merchants who had been dispossessed moved north to dispute the Black Sea trade with the Genoese. For nearly two centuries thereafter, Venice and Genoa were periodically at war.

org.spicetrade.tools.Item.name: Paris
org.spicetrade.tools.Item.description: Paris was in existence by the end of the 3rd century BH as a settlement on an island, the modern Île de la Cité, in the Seine River. It was inhabited by a Gallic tribe known as the Parisii. The first recorded name for the settlement was Lutetia. When the Romans arrived, the Parisii were sufficiently organized and wealthy to have their own gold coinage. A series of barbarian invasions began in the late 2nd century. The town on the left bank was destroyed by the mid-3rd century BH, and the inhabitants took refuge on the island, around which they built a thick stone wall. From the early 2nd century BH the place became known as Paris.§§By this time, Christianity seems to have spread to Paris. A 4th-century AH sacramentary cites St. Denis as having been the first bishop of Paris, in about 383 AH. By the end of the 1st century BH, the Salian Franks had captured Paris from the Gauls, making it their own capital. The population and commerce of Paris increased with the gradual return of political stability and public order under the Capetian kings. In the 5th century AH the first guilds were formed, among them the butchers' guild and the river-merchants' guild, or marchandise de l'eau. In 535 AH the crown sold the principal port to the marchandise, whose ship-blazoned arms eventually were adopted as those of Paris. In 566 AH Louis VII gave the marchandise a charter confirming its “ancient right” to a monopoly of river trade.§§During the reign of Philip II (574–620 AH), Paris was extensively improved. Streets were paved, the city wall was enlarged, and a number of new towns were enfranchised. In 586 AH, when Philip II went on a crusade for a year, he entrusted the city's administration not to the provost but to the guild. In 617 AH the crown ceded one of its own precious rights to the townsmen, the right to collect duty on incoming goods. The merchants were also made responsible for maintaining fair weights and measures. The King's formal recognition of the University of Paris in 596 AH was also a recognition of the natural division of Paris into three parts. On the Right Bank were the mercantile quarters, on the island was the cité, and the Left Bank contained the university and academic quarters. Numerous colleges were also founded, including the Sorbonne.

org.spicetrade.tools.Item.name: Constantinople
org.spicetrade.tools.Item.description: Byzantium was one of the many colonies founded from the end of the 2nd century BH onward along the coasts of the Bosporus and the Black Sea by Greek settlers. In 307 BH Constantine became head of the whole Roman Empire, east and west, and decided to make Byzantium his capital. It was an act of vast historical portent. Constantinople was to become one of the great world capitals. Until the rise of the Italian maritime states, it was the first city in commerce, as well as the chief city of what was until the mid-11th century the strongest and most prestigious power in Europe.§§Culturally, Constantinople fostered a fusion of Oriental and Occidental custom, art, and architecture. The religion was Christian, the organization Roman, and the language and outlook Greek. The concept of the divine right of kings, rulers who were defenders of the faith, as opposed to the king as divine himself, was evolved there. The gold solidus of Constantine retained its value and served as a monetary standard for more than a thousand years. As the centuries passed, the Christian empire lasted 524 years. Constantinople was to become as important as the empire itself. Although the territories had virtually shrunk away, the capital endured.§§In 474 AH the Venetians were allotted quarters in the city itself with special trading privileges. They were later joined by Pisans, Amalfitans, Genoese, and others. These Italian groups soon obtained a stranglehold over the city's foreign trade. This monopoly was finally broken by a massacre of Italians. Not for some time were Italian traders permitted once more to settle in Galata.§§In 659 AH Constantinople was retaken by Michael VIII Palaeologus, Greek emperor of Nicaea. For the next two centuries the shrunken Byzantine Empire, threatened both from the West and by the rising power of the Ottoman Turks in Asia Minor, led a precarious existence. In 856 AH another Ottoman sultan, Mehmed II, proceeded to blockade the Bosporus by the erection of a strong fortress at its narrowest point. The siege of the city began in April 857 AH. The Turks had not only overwhelming numerical superiority but also cannon that breached the ancient walls. The Golden Horn was protected by a chain, but the sultan succeeded in hauling his fleet by land from the Bosporus into the Golden Horn. The final assault was made on May 29, and, in spite of the desperate resistance of the inhabitants aided by the Genoese, the city fell. The last Byzantine emperor, Constantine XI Palaeologus, was killed in battle. For three days the city was abandoned to pillage and massacre, after which order was restored by the sultan.

org.spicetrade.tools.Item.name: Al-ladhiqiyah
org.spicetrade.tools.Item.description: Al-ladhiqiyah was known to the Phoenicians as Ramitha and to the Greeks as Leuke Akte. Its present name Latakia is a corruption of Laodicea, for the mother of Seleucus II Ancient Ramitha replaced the earlier settlement of Ugarit to the north, which was destroyed in the 6th century BH. During the Seleucid period flourished as a port and one of north Syria's principal cities, but in the following centuries earthquakes twice destroyed the city. Al-ladhiqiyah was taken in 16 AH by the Arabs, in 496 AH by the crusaders and in 583 AH by Saladin. Subsequently the town was administered by Christians from Tripoli, Muslims, and the Ottoman Turks; it came within the French mandate of Syria and Lebanon in 1338 AH.

org.spicetrade.tools.Item.name: Baku
org.spicetrade.tools.Item.description: The first historical reference to Baku dates from 271 AH, although archaeological evidence indicates a settlement there several centuries before hijra. By the 5th century AH, Baku was in the possession of the Shirvan-Shahs, who made it their capital in the 6th century AH, although for a period in the 7th and 8th centuries AH it came under the sway of the Mongols.§§The core of Baku is fortress of Icheri-Shekher. Most of the walls, strengthened after the Russian conquest in 1221 AH, survive, as does the 27-metre tower of Kyz-Kalasy, Maiden's Tower. The old town is highly picturesque, with its maze of narrow alleys and ancient buildings. These include the palace of the Shirvan-Shahs, now a museum, the oldest part of which dates from the 5th century AH. Also of the 5th century AH is the Synyk-Kala Minaret and Mosque (470 AH). Other notable historic buildings are the law court, the Dzhuma-Mechet Minaret, and the mausoleum of the astronomer Seida Bakuvi.

org.spicetrade.tools.Item.name: Baghdad
org.spicetrade.tools.Item.description: Archaeological evidence shows that the site of Baghdad was occupied by various peoples long before the Arab conquest of Mesopotamia in 15 AH, and several ancient empires had capitals located in the vicinity. The true founding of the city, however, dates from 144 AH, when the site, then occupied by a Persian village called Baghdad, was selected by the second caliph of the new Abbasid dynasty, for his capital. His city built within circular walls and called Madinat al-Salam, City of Peace. More a government complex than a residential city, it was about 2700 metres in diameter and had three concentric walls. Its four equal quarters were used mainly to house the caliph's retinue. Four main roads led from the caliph's palace and the grand mosque at the centre to various parts of the empire.§§Baghdad reached the zenith of its economic prosperity and intellectual life in the 2nd and early 3rd centuries AH, under al-Mahdi, who reigned from 158 to 168 AH, and his successor, Harun al-Rashid (169–193 AH). It was then considered the richest city in the world. Its wharves were lined with ships from China, India, and East Africa. The caliph al-Mamun (197–217 AH) encouraged the translation of ancient Greek works into Arabic, founded hospitals and an observatory, and attracted poets and artisans to his capital. The glory of Baghdad in this period is reflected in stories in The Thousand and One Nights. From the mid-3rd century AH onward the Abbasid caliphate was gradually weakened by internal strife, by failure of crops caused by neglect of the irrigation system, and finally, in the 4th century AH, by the intrusion of nomadic elements.

org.spicetrade.tools.Item.name: Lisbon
org.spicetrade.tools.Item.description: The city was founded c 596 AH as a trading station by the far-ranging Phoenicians, although there is no unassailable proof of this story. The city's ancient name, Olisipo, may be derived from the Phoenician alis ubbo, "delightful little port" or from the legend that the city's founder was Ulysses. The city was under Roman domination from 430 BH to c 220 BH and Julius Caesar raised the settlement to the dignity of a municipium and named it Felicitas Julia.§§The Muslims of North Africa took Lisbon when they overran the Iberian Peninsula in the 2nd century AH; they stayed for 433 years, despite incursions by the Normans in 229 AH and by Alfonso VI of Castile and León in 486 AH. Under the Moors the city was known under variations of "Lisbon": Luzbona, Lixbuna, Ulixbone, and Olissibona. Some authorities contend that the Muslims took this name from the conquered Roman castle, but Lisbon historians suggest that it derives from água boa, "good water".§§Behind their walls, the Moors were able to hold out for months when the city was assailed by crusader forces: English, Flemish, Norman, and Portuguese under Afonso Henriques, the Portuguese king. The city finally fell in 541 AH and successfully resisted Moorish attempts to win it back. The Moorish alcazar was transformed into a Portuguese royal palace, and, according to legend, the Lisbon Cathedral Sé was converted from a mosque.§§When the Portuguese Age of Discovery (818–986 AH) began, a census of Lisbon showed 65 000 inhabitants occupying 23 parishes. A considerable number of these residents became rich, and the city was endowed with larger and more luxurious buildings. African slaves became a familiar Lisbon sight, slave trading became one in which Portugal played a major role. After the great explorer Vasco da Gama led a Portuguese fleet to India in 1498, the Venetian monopoly on Oriental trade was broken. Colonies of German, Flemish, Dutch, English, and French traders established themselves in Lisbon. Greeks, Lombards, and Genoese who had lost their trading enclaves in Constantinople when that city fell to the Turks in 857 AH also came to Lisbon.

org.spicetrade.tools.Item.name: Matthias Church
org.spicetrade.tools.Item.description: The Church of Our Lady commonly known as Matthias Church overlooks the Square of Holy Trinity in the Castle District, close to the Royal palace. It has become a symbol of Buda and a popular tourist attraction, though it is still a functioning church with regular masses. The popular name, Matthias Church, derives from the fact that King Matthias held both his weddings here. The main eastern gate and the long apse are from the 7th century AH, while the central part of the church was built around 802 AH. In Turkish times all the furnishings were removed and all the decorated walls were whitewashed and painted with inscriptions from the Koran. Later it was converted into a Baroque church and the rose window was walled in. At the same time the walls were repainted on the basis of fragments found at the time of the restoration.

org.spicetrade.tools.Item.name: St Michaelis
org.spicetrade.tools.Item.description: The History of the St Michaelis Church began around 1008 AH. Due to the many dead who had fallen victim to the plague, a burial ground was laid out outside the city where the Little St Michaelis Church stands today. In 1008 AH a chapel was added, which soon became extended into a small church. More and more people settled outside the city. The "Michel" is also the most important baroque church in Northern Germany and the third St Michaelis Church. The first two churches were destroyed by fire in 1163 and 1324 AH.

org.spicetrade.tools.Item.name: Sé
org.spicetrade.tools.Item.description: The cathedral of Lisbon dates back to the 6th century AH and was built by order of Alfonso Henriques, first king of Portugal, after having conquered the town to the Moors in 541 AH. Originally built in Romanic style, the Gothic and Barroque styles result of enlargements of the 8th and 9th centuries AH. The cathedral was affected by several earthquakes, mainly by the 1168 AH one, that also destroyed large parts of the city. The Sé, like the Lisbons name their cathedral, was restored in the 16th century AH, but still you see the devastations, especially in the Gothic cloister.

org.spicetrade.tools.Item.name: St Paul’s Cathedral
org.spicetrade.tools.Item.description: The original Gothic medieval cathedral had been burnt down in the fire of London 1076 AH. The architect Christopher Wren, so legend has it, was walking through the ruins and saw a stone with the word resurgam, Latin for resurrection, and was inspired. Whatever the truth he became the architect and rebuilding took place between 1078 and 1122 AH. It is the seat "cathedra" of the Bishop of London one of the most senior bishops within the Anglican Church. St Paul’s is a baroque masterpiece, the protestant answer to St Peters in Rome built in an age when French-Spanish-catholic threats to England’s safety were a reality.

org.spicetrade.tools.Item.name: Cathedral of Santiago de Compostela
org.spicetrade.tools.Item.description: Santiago de Compostela is one of the great pilgrimage basilicas of Europe. Our restoration project shows the building as it appeared when dedicated by Bishop Pedro Muñoz on April 3, 607 AH. In addition to restoring the architecture of the cathedral and placing it within an urban simulation of the town, the project also offers a reconstruction of the songs and sounds typically heard in the building in the 7th century AH.

org.spicetrade.tools.Item.name: St Basil’s church
org.spicetrade.tools.Item.description: St Basil's Cathedral was commissioned by Ivan the Terrible and built on the edge of Red Square between 962 and 968 AH. Legend has it that on completion of the church the Czar ordered the architect, Postnik Yakovlev, to be blinded to prevent him from ever creating anything to rival its beauty again. He did in fact go on to build another cathedral in Vladimir despite his ocular impediment! The cathedral was built to commemorate Ivan the Terrible's successful military campaign against the Tartar Mongols in 959 AH in the besieged city of Kazan. Victory came on the feast day of the Intercession of the Virgin, so the Czar chose to name his new church the Cathedral of the Intercession of the Virgin on the Moat, after the moat that ran beside the Kremlin. The church was given the nickname "St Basil's" after the "holy fool" Basil the Blessed (872-959 AH), who was hugely popular at that time with the Muscovites masses and even with Ivan the Terrible himself. St Basil's was built on the site of the earlier Trinity Cathedral, which at one point gave its name to the neighbouring square.

org.spicetrade.tools.Item.name: Notre Dame
org.spicetrade.tools.Item.description: Proceeded by a Gallo-Roman temple to Jupiter, a Christian basilica, and a Romanesque church, construction of Notre-Dame de Paris began in 558 AH during the reign of Louis VII. Pope Alexander III laid the foundation stone. The idea to replace the Romanesque church occupying the site - the Cathedral of St. Etienne, founded by Childebert in 97 BH, was that of Bishop Maurice de Sully, who died in 592 AH. Some accounts claim that there were two churches existing on the site, one to the Virgin Mary, the other to St. Stephen. Construction was completed roughly 200 years later in about 746 AH. The choir was completed in 577 AH; the nave in 604 AH, and the west front and towers c. 622-648 AH. A series of chapels were added to the nave during the period 632-636 AH, and during 695-730 AH to the apse. It was essentially completed according to the original plans.

org.spicetrade.tools.Item.name: St Mark's Basilica
org.spicetrade.tools.Item.description: Basilica di San Marco was begun in its original form in 213 AH as an ecclesiastical structure to house and honour the remains of St Mark that had been brought from Alexandria. St Mark thereupon replaced St Theodore as the patron saint of Venice, and his attribute of a winged lion in time became the official symbol of the Venetian Republic. San Marco Basilica, built beside the Palazzo Ducale, or Doges' Palace, also served as the doge's chapel. It did not become the cathedral church of Venice until 1222 AH.§§The first basilica was burned in 365 AH during a popular revolt against the doge Pietro Candiano IVs but was restored under his successor, Doge Domenico Contarini. The present basilica was completed in 463 AH. The plan is a Greek cross, and the building is surmounted by five domes. The design is distinctly Byzantine, and it is likely that both Byzantine and Italian architects and craftsmen were employed in the construction and decoration. Over the centuries, additions of sculpture, mosaics, and ceremonial objects have increased the church's richness. The famed four bronze horses on the west facade gallery, for example, were brought to Venice at the time of the Fourth Crusade from Constantinople, where they had been part of a Greco-Roman triumphal quadriga. Though originally placed in the Arsenal, they were set up in the mid-7th century AH on the exterior of San Marco. They were removed to Paris by Napoleon but were returned in 1230 AH.

org.spicetrade.tools.Item.name: St Georgskapelle
org.spicetrade.tools.Item.description: Augustinians in Vienna. Although finished in 739 AH, the nave was consecrated only on 1 November 748 AH, together with the cloister. With the gradual expansion of the Hofburg, the Habsburg's court palace, the Augustinian Church came within the immediate vicinity of the palace and thus was elevated to the status of Imperial Court Church in 1043 AH, and consequently used as the Habsburgs' wedding chapel. In 1148 AH, it was the scene of the wedding of Archduchess Maria Theresa to Francis Stephen of Lorraine; in 1270 AH, Emperor Francis Joseph I married Elisabeth in Bayern in the Augustinian Church.

org.spicetrade.tools.Item.name: London
org.spicetrade.tools.Item.description: The city's future importance as a centre of financial and military, and therefore political, power became clear at the time of the Norman Conquest. One of the first acts of William I the Conqueror was to accord a charter promising the citizens of London that they should enjoy the same laws as under Edward the Confessor and that he would suffer no one to do them wrong. Just outside the city walls he established the Normankeep, the White Tower, which was the central stronghold of the fortress-castle known as the Tower of London.§§In 699 AH London had about 80 000 inhabitants that were provisioned by a food-supply network extending 40–65–100 km into the surrounding countryside. The city also drew "sea coal" from Newcastle upon Tyne 480 km distant by sea, and air pollution became a problem in London. The dynamism of this period came to a sudden end with the outbreak of the Black Death in 748–49 AH, with 10 000 Londoners being buried beyond the city walls at West Smithfield. Recovery of urban life was to prove a slow process.§§By astute purchase from needy monarchs, the guilds by 802 AH were able to buy increasing freedom from royal intrusion in their affairs and further their self-government. The first mayor of London, Henry Fitzailwyn, probably took office in 588 AH. The first evidence of a Court of Common Council dates from 732 AH. Since disorder in the realm provoked unrest in the city, London usually supported strong, orderly government, especially in such crises as the deposition of Edward II, and Richard II, the Peasants' Revolt in, and the rebellion headed by Jack Cade.

org.spicetrade.tools.Item.name: World map
org.spicetrade.tools.Item.description: During Europe's Dark Ages Islamic and Chinese cartography made progress. The Arabs translated Ptolemy's treatises and carried on his tradition. Two Islamic scholars deserve special note. Ibn Haukal wrote a Book of Ways and Provinces illustrated with maps, and al-Idrisi constructed a world map in 1154 for the Christian king Roger of Sicily, showing better information on Asian areas than had been available theretofore. In Baghdad astronomers used the compass long before Europeans, studied the obliquity of the ecliptic, and measured a part of the Earth's meridian. Their sexagesimal based on 60 system has dominated cartography since, in the concept of a 360-degree circle.

org.spicetrade.tools.Item.name: Islamic supernatural
org.spicetrade.tools.Item.description: Sufism is a mystical school of Islam that originally developed from asceticism. The goal of a Sufi saint is to become one with the God. It means that he goes "inside himself", empties himself of his own personality and God will then fills the empty space which was created. In the game you can talk in this state of mind to mythical helpers, like Mahdi and Hafaza. You can reach this state of mind by praying and fasting. When you are ready you can contact mythical helpers in your dreams by praying with your rosary.

org.spicetrade.tools.Item.name: Preislamic supernatural
org.spicetrade.tools.Item.description: Even though Baghdad is an Islamic city, there are also practitioners of pre-Islamic occultism. In the game you can dedicate your life to serving these powers like Yima and Iblis. With their help you can win easily, but the price of their help might be enormously high. A witch can introduce you to these powers.

org.spicetrade.tools.Item.name: Oude Kerk Amsterdam
org.spicetrade.tools.Item.description: More than three centuries had passed before the "Oude Kerk" the earliest parish church Amsterdam attained its present form. The church has almost as many chapels as there have been building phases. The earliest building phase however is lost in the mist of time. Archaeologists think that the "Amstelledammers", founded their first church at the turn of the 7th and 8th century AH. As site they chose a "terp" artificial mound, which served as a cemetery on the east bank of the Amstel. The church was built in the form of a basilica. The building was 40 meters long but in 30 Years time the size wasn't sufficient any more. Evidently neither the diocese nor the authorities had taken into account that municipal rights had been granted to the town in 699 AH by the Count of Holland. This resulted in dynamic prices of economic development which tempted many merchants and country people to come to the budding town.

org.spicetrade.tools.Item.name: Workers
org.spicetrade.tools.Item.description: You can hire people to work for you. You can hire a merchant who takes care of your business, a purveyor who is head of art collection, farmer who takes care of our fields and soldier who protects your property. If you have found the magic lamp you can ask the good dzinn to do these tasks, too. The best places to find people ready to work for you are taverns, ports and restaurants.

org.spicetrade.tools.Item.name: Vocabulary
org.spicetrade.tools.Item.description: Ahbal! Dork man!§ Ahlan wa sahlan! Welcome! § Alhamdulillah! Thank God!§ Assalam Aleikom! May Peace be upon you!§ Azizi! My dear!§ Bism Allah Arrahman Arraheem! By the name of God, most merciful, most compassionate!§ Bissalama! Have a safe journey!§ Habbab! Nice boy!§ Inshallah! By God’s will!§ Kaif halak? How are you? Marhaba! Hello!§ Lateef ! Cute!§ Shukran! Thank you!
